body.name: The Librarian of Burned Books: A Novel

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Same thing happening today
reviews.reviewText: So scary that this book about the 1930 ‘s and 40’s book banning and the rise of fascism is so on topic for what is happening to our politics in the US RIGHT NOW!! For anyone that thinks banning books and watching this unfold in the US and is for the people pushing all this I DARE you to read this account of what happened before and still see if you feel the same. The people pushing this crap in this country are NOT your friend and definitely are your enemy. Read a true account of what happens when you allow people to oppress another and the circumstances of that oppression…This is a quote from the book. “There are moments in life when you have to put what is right over what party you vote for. And if you can’t recognize those moments when the stakes are low, let me assure you won’t recognize them when the stakes are high”. How true.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A World War II book written for our time
reviews.reviewText: The novel is about books that banned and censured. The Nazi burned at least hundreds of thousands of books in the 1930's and the Countries to the West reacted as one can have expected they would. During the Second World War efforts were made to send paperback books to GIs fighting in Europe and Asia to give soldiers some diversion in the midst of the horrors around them. These two and interconnected mid-century events are explored in this novel and implications made concerning life today.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars This book is so relevant today!
reviews.reviewText: In May 1933, Nazis oversaw the burning of thousands of books, beginning their ban on any ideas that did not follow lockstep with their dictatorial world view.In 2022-23, the state of Florida removed over two thousand books from school libraries because someone—often a single person—objected to the book. One man alone, who has no children in the public school system, was able to demand removal of over 600 titles.Books ranged from classics like Tom Sawyer to Pulitzer Prize winners. As in Nazi Germany, many were written by people of color,or members of the LGBTQ+ community.In this novel, the characters Hannah says this:Few people have to watch their country die. I have had that dubious privilege and I can tell you that it comes not as a rebel shout but as a sly whisper. . .it can start with rumblings about an unreliable press. . that will threaten your family, your children.. . .it comes cloaked in patriotism.This book resonates with me, a lifelong reader and retired English teacher. The story is well written and the historical perspectives in both Germany of the 1930’s and American politics in the 1940’s are valuable

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beautifully written, timely, and historically accurate
reviews.reviewText: If I could wish you to read one book, I think this would be it. It takes place in Germany, France, and the US during the 1930s and 40s and follows three characters. Young American writer Althea James and Hannah Brecht meet in Berlin in 1933 and their story is told by Althea. Hannah Brecht is Jewish and a lesbian who has fled Germany and in 1936 is in Paris working at the German Library of Burned Books before the Germans invade. Vivian Childs is in New York in 1944 and working to fight an amendment to a bill that censors Armed Service Editions shipped to the millions of service men overseas. It is also a cautionary tale for our time. There may be a few instances of it being a bit heavy-handed, but it really doesn't distract much.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2024
reviews.reviewText: A sort of interesting book. It jumps timelines regularly while still dealing with the same characters. The historical side was something I was unaware of originally. However, the book made me want to look into it further. Overall the characters and history were enjoyable. But due to the constantly changing timelines it felt to me as if the story moved too slowly.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Wonderful Bo ok!
reviews.reviewText: This book should be required reading because it is so on topic RIGHT NOW with what the US is experiencing! It gives the reader an important perspective of what Democracy holds dear and can’t afford to loose! Please read this book!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Book Burning Baddies
reviews.reviewText: "The Librarian of Burned Books" is a powerful and emotionally resonant novel that revolves around three central characters: Viv, Hannah, and Althea. There are three narratives running throughout the story, which eventually come together.The underlying issue of the book is the Nazi rise to power and their use of censorship, specifically book burning that is the central character if you will. This novel delves into the profound impact of censorship and book burning on its three central characters: Viv, Hannah, and Althea. Albeit, at different times. Through their experiences, the book highlights the devastating consequences of cultural suppression and the resilient human spirit in the face of such adversity.In "The Librarian of Burned Books," censorship and book burning are not just historical events; they are central forces that shape the lives and choices of the characters. The novel vividly portrays the emotional and intellectual toll that censorship takes on individuals and communities. It underscores the importance of preserving cultural heritage and the power of literature to inspire resistance and resilience."The Librarian of Burned Books" is a compelling exploration of the profound consequences of censorship and book burning on the lives of its three main characters. Their stories serve as a powerful reminder of the enduring value of literature and the indomitable human spirit in the face of attempts to silence knowledge and ideas. This novel is a moving tribute to those who have fought to protect intellectual freedom and cultural heritage throughout history. Each one of them had to figure how to find enough strength to be the hero of their personal story.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars engrossing historical fiction
reviews.reviewText: The start of the fall of Germany has always intrigued me. The author’s writing style is addictive to read. The fictional characters added into the actual history in this story was very well done. I loved the characters.And all Americans should take note and realize that what is going on in our own country right now is parallel to what happened in 1933 Germany and step up to stop it.
Loved the back and forth between the main characters as their stories were told. Loved the ending but I like happy ones as it doesn't happen too often. Would recommend if you are into the war years.
Terrible time in our history, told by a gifted author, with a message that is as relevant today as was then.

reviews.reviewTitle: I’m sure the story is great but the condition of the book is not great.
reviews.reviewText: I bought the book as a gift and frankly, the actual book looked like someone has read this copy already. I don’t have time to return and order a new copy but it is annoying when books arrive looking like they are second hand. If I wanted a second hand copy, I’d have ordered one. :(
